chapter.title: System Administration
chapter.para: Before you can begin processing retail sales, you must first set up xTuple POS to reflect your retail operation—and give users the required permissions to use the retail package. These activities should be completed by a retail operations manager or dedicated information technology professional. In this chapter we'll cover the following topics:
Once these configurations are complete, you can begin selling products!

section.title: Configuring User Permissions
section.para: xTuple ERP has the powerful ability to manage user permissions, enabling you to allow or disallow access to various functional areas of the system. For example, a sales associate may only have privileges to process sales, while the store manager may have the ability to maintain registers, view inventory, and process sales.

There are several options available to you when managing system users. You can either A) assign individual permissions to users B) create preconfigured groups of permissions and assign individuals to these groups or C) a combination of A and B.
The following path will get you to the screen for maintaining system users: System > Maintain Users.
In this scenario, let's say we have a new sales associate whose permissions we want to review. To begin, follow these steps:

listitem.para: Highlight the user whose permissions we want to review
Select the EDIT button (or double-click on the user)

section.para: As you can see, the basic user information—such as name and email address—has already been entered. The user also has several Sales module privileges, which you can see under the "Granted Privileges" section. We can add or remove privileges (by module) simply by selecting a specific privilege, and then choosing either the ADD or REVOKE button.

tip.para: Use the ADD ALL and REVOKE ALL buttons to move all the privileges at once for the specified module

section.para: To learn which groups our sample user belongs to, we select the "Groups" tab. The following screen appears:
In this case, the following user groups have been defined:

As you can see, our user has been granted the privileges for the SALES ASSOCIATE group. If we wanted to change the group the user belonged to, we could simply use the ADD or REVOKE buttons. We could also add individual privileges to the user's existing group privileges by using the same buttons on the "Privileges" tab.

tip.para: The user group feature makes it easy to define logical sets of privileges defined according to standard job roles. The following path takes you to the screen for defining group privileges: System > Maintain Groups.

section.para: To review the Sites our sample user has access to, select the "Sites" tab. The following screen will appear:

Since our user is a sales associate at the ST1 Site, he only has permission to access this one Site. If, on the other hand, he were an operations manager, he might have permissions to access every Site. This would enable him to review inventory levels or sales reports across the entire operation.

section.title: Configuring the Sales Module
section.para: The first step in configuring xTuple POS is to enter some basic global information. To do this, navigate to the Sales Configuration screen in the System module, using the following steps:

listitem.para: Follow this path: System > Configure Modules > Sales

section.para: All retail transactions automatically receive a unique ID number. On the Sales Configuration screen you define which number you want to use as the starting point for these unique identifiers. You can choose any initial number you wish.

tip.para: To ensure you are collecting customer information at the point of sale, be sure not to select the "Use internal customer for all Retail Sales" option.

section.para: In addition, you have the option on this screen to decide if you want to collect customer data at the point of sale—such as customer name, address, and phone number—or not. If you prefer not to collect this information, then select the "Disable choosing Customer at Cash Register" option. This will cause the customer tab on the Cash Register screen to be hidden from view. To learn more about the system-wide options for configuring the Retail package, please see the xTuple Reference Guide.

Finally, you will need to determine whether the Tax Zone for your Retail sales is drawn from the Site record or from the Customer record. If you are not collecting Customer information at the point of sale, then the Site option would be your choice.

section.title: Creating Retail Sites
section.para: In xTuple ERP, we define "Sites" as physical locations where you operate your business. For example, in the PostBooks Edition—our free ERP offering—we provide you with the ability to manage a single Site. A Site can be a store front, warehouse, or corporate office. One of the benefits of the commercial versions of xTuple ERP—that is, the Standard and Manufacturing editions—is that you gain the ability to manage multiple Sites, including any combination of Site types. Depending on your level of permissions, the multi-Site capability gives you the ability to track sales remotely at multiple stores and also monitor inventory levels at each Site.

note.para: The examples used in this product guide are based on having xTuple POS loaded into the Manufacturing Edition of xTuple ERP.

section.para: Sites are added (or edited) in the Inventory module. The following path will get you there: Inventory > Site > List. The following screen shows a list of the two store front operations we will be using throughout this product guide: ST1 and ST2. We will later assign Cash Register terminals to these Sites.

note.para: Keep in mind, Sites are not necessarily limited to store fronts only. Warehouses, factories, and business offices may also be identified as Sites.

tip.para: Make sure when creating a new Site that you enter a Tax Authority on the General tab for each Site that will have a store front. Sales taxes will be calculated by the Cash Register windows based on the Tax Authority defined at the Site level.

section.para: Once you enter your list of Sites, the next step is to define Retail Sites. The difference between "Sites" and "Retail Sites" is that Retails Sites hold additional information specific to the xTuple POS package. For example, default cost accounts and Cash Register terminals are defined at the Retail Site level. The following path will get you to the Retail Sites screen: Sales > Master Information > Retail Sites.

As you can see in our example, we have already created the Retail Site for the ST1 Site. We will now demonstrate how this was done by creating a Retail Site for the ST2 Site. To begin creating a new Retail Site, select the NEW button. The following screen will appear:
On this screen complete the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose the Site you want to define as a Retail Site
Specify how long you want Quotes to remain active for this Retail Site
Assign default cost accounts assigned to the Retail Site
Indicate the Bank Account(s) used by this Retail Site for depositing and transferring funds

section.para: The next step is to define Terminals to associate with the Retail Site. Terminals are required when using a Cash Register, as will be discussed in later chapters. To define a Terminal, select the "Terminals" tab and complete the following steps:

listitem.para: Type in the name of the Terminal in the line provided (e.g., Terminal 2a)
Again select the ADD button if more Terminals are needed

section.para: Now that our Retail Sites have been created, we can begin managing the Cash Registers and processing sales!
